text: oh that's very good advice! thanks for that Sachin
and currently, I dont have any experience with coding
I'll definitely look into that
do you have any recommendations of where to start?

Also Sachin, I would love to know more about your daily work routine and your position at the moment. I would also love to hear about the past experiences as well! I feel like it would be a great way for me to see how someone successful like you has progressed through the industry and it would be a nice way to get to know you
and I would also like to understand what you enjoy doing when you aren't working and what kind of hobbies and interests you have, essentially, I would like to know you better :slightly_smiling_face:
:grin:
and I can share my experiences on what it's like at my university and my course as well as what's going on outside of my school life

No problem at all :) 
If you mean recommendations on where to start for coding , 
I’d say start with some basic python . 
Python is pretty simple to start learning and you don’t really need advanced knowledge of the language for Nuke scripting. ( there are a couple of really good python courses on Udemy if you are looking for a structured video lessons ) . Or you could use on of the the python books . You can always ask me if you have trouble understanding any of the concepts . 
Once you understand the basics you can start looking at some Nuke script examples ( can find a lot of them on Nukepedia) and understanding them won’t be an issue casue it’s basically python for Nuke . That’s for later though. To start with , keep it simple and just try understanding the basics of python .
At the moment, I’m working as a Pipeline TD focussing on the Animation part of the pipeline. I used to be a compositing TD up until 6 months ago when I made the shift to animation .

As a TD the nature of my job is the same irrespective of the discipline. It involves 
- technical support ( for example when tools break, they need to be updated to handle the cases hat broke them ) 
- fire fighting . this is where we write quick python scripts that do a specific task . For example , when the artist has to process a large amount of data in a repetitive fashion and it would take them a long time to do it by hand . We’d write a script that can automate this process and do it for them . 
- development . For example building new / better tools that are designed to make artist’s life easier . 

That an overview of my main responsibilities. Being a pipeline TDalso means  Being responsible for keeping an eye on how data flows between deparments . So in my case , it would be looking at how/ where  data comes into animation and how/ where it goes out . 
Does that make sense ?
Funnily enough though , I did not start as a developer. I started my career as a Roto artist :)

I was trying to learn comp and once I moved to comp ,played around with python scripting . my then manager asked me if I would like to do that full time as there was a need for someone who understood the artistic side of things as well as the technical . 
I thought about it and by then I had actually started to like the technical side of it so it was an easy decision .

When I’m not working , I’m usually playing some  sport or learning music . Have a few different interests/ hobbies  but those are the ones I do religiously.  Lol 
Do I remember you saying you play football ?
wow
you inspire me :joy:
I play football but I'm not sure if I said it directly to you
I'm definitely going to utilise my library then for python
I'll take a look at Udemy and Nukepedia
my school has a very nice learning and teaching environment from my perspective
it strives to meet the expectations of the students, our course is relatively new, we're the about to be the 3rd year that graduates
we got a motion capture studio about 2 years ago now, and it's amazing how many facilities we have to promote our studies
it's pretty sad, one of our lecturers is leaving this semester, he was definitely the most knowledgeable and experienced

he was the CTO of and co-founded the Imaginarium studios before he came to teach, and now hes moving onto Deep Silver Dambuster studios in nottingham as a mocap coordinator or something, I cant quite remember
he was the lecturer in charge of all our nuke and 3dequalizer modules
we also have a technician that used to work for an vfx studio that focused primarily on advertising, he does most of the demonstrations in nuke and 3dequalizer
but yeah, I'm in a great place to find my way
and now I've met you and it just feels great! I'm really grateful for your support and friendship
